Bulk nomination is undermining patient choice.

And it has created a completely unfair playing field.

Some PMR systems allow pharmacies to switch patients back in bulk, without consent and without a conversation. Patients have no idea their nomination has changed behind their backs.

Pharmacies who refuse to do this lose business.
Pharmacies who do it gain business.
That isn't fair competition. It's a broken system.

Bulk switching goes directly against patient choice.
And it punishes the pharmacies who try to do the right thing.

There are only two legitimate scenarios for a bulk nomination change:
‚Ä¢ When a pharmacy is sold
‚Ä¢ When two pharmacies merge
And even then, the NHS manages the change ‚Äî not the PMR system.

Everywhere else, nomination should stay where it belongs:
with the patient.

# LinkedIn Caption ‚Äì Safy's Chemist Carousel

Post date: 2025-12-17 (2 days after blog publication on 2025-12-15)

Platform: LinkedIn

Creative ID: 2025-12-17-97-percent-fewer-near-misses-carousel

---

Safy's Chemist on Melton Road has served its community for 45 years. Today, it's one of the busiest pharmacies in the area, dispensing 14,500 items every month.

A year ago, the pharmacy was averaging 5-6 near misses per month. Pharmacist Asif was spending his entire nine-hour day checking prescriptions, running back and forth between the consultation room and dispensary. Baskets piling up. Constant worry about patient safety.

Since switching to Titan, near misses have dropped to just 2 in an entire year.

The improvement is so significant that Asif jokes about inspector skepticism: "I'm worried the inspector is going to come in, look at my near misses, and say, 'You can't have only made two mistakes in a year.'"

This doesn't happen by asking people to be more careful. It happens when safety is designed into the workflow‚Äîwhen barcode scanning prevents wrong products from reaching patients, when the system won't let staff seal a bag if items are missing, when every item is tracked with batch numbers and expiry dates.

The numbers tell the story. But the real story is what changed: from constant worry to calm control, from chaos to confidence.

The patient comes first. 

Stop nomination ping-pong.

The NHS Electronic Prescription Service is one of the most advanced prescribing systems in the world. It works because patient nomination is meant to be clear, deliberate, and respected.

But there is a flaw. Some systems can automatically reverse a patient's pharmacy nomination, without the patient knowing.

When that happens, prescriptions can bounce between pharmacies. Patients lose clarity about where their medicines are. Trust takes the hit first. And pharmacies playing fair are put at a disadvantage.

At scale, this creates risk for EPS itself. It was not designed for businesses to fight over nominations through automation.

We were asked to build this functionality. We refused. Not because we couldn't, but because it breaches our values around patient safety, professional standards, and fair competition.

Patient choice must mean something.

Can you spot the difference?

The GTIN doesn't.

Right now in UK pharmacy, different medicines are arriving with the same GTIN barcode or a GTIN that does not match the product inside.

When that happens, the scanner passes the wrong medicine as correct. Every safety layer collapses.

Pharmacists are forced to slow down, override the check, and carry the risk that should sit with manufacturers and regulators.

This is not a workflow problem. It is a patient safety problem.

The fix is simple:
‚Ä¢ Make accurate GTIN barcodes mandatory
‚Ä¢ Treat incorrect GTINs as labelling errors
‚Ä¢ Protect the final safety check that keeps patients safe

If you work in pharmacy, please add your name.
This is a small action that protects every dispenser in the country.
